bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 22, 1921

div1.p: Hanson reports on the investigation of a possible yellow fever case. He describes his field work and discusses personnel matters. He hopes to bring the campaign to an end by the spring of 1922.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 22, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
Contra la Fiebre Amarilla
EN LOS
Departamentos del Norte
____
TRUJILLO
__
Trujillo, Perú
November 22, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Asst Surgeon General, U.S.P.H.S.,
Washington, D.C.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I last wrote you aboard the S.S. Peru
on my way to Lima to investigate the rumor of a case of yellow
fever reported from Callao. When we arrived the case was dead
and buried and we could get no other information than history
and the autopsy findings. These were pretty evident that the
case was one of pernicious malaria, but there were also other
symptoms and findings which makes it a bit difficult to be
certain that there was not something more in addition to the
malaria. The man had a very marked astenia and turned very
yellow before death. He had vomiting, and bleeding gums, nose
bleed and other symptoms quite typical of yellow fever accor-
ding to Quiroz who saw him twice. In the autopsy they found
a very marked congestion of the mucous membranes all the way
down, kidneys showed an acute nephritis. Echymoses in the lungs
etc, but the liver was not of the typical mustard yellow color
which one finds in cases of several days duration. The liver
was rather of a darker color and with more bleeding than one
usually encounters in autopsies on yellow fever bodies.

Another point the case came from Casma, in the Depart-
ment of Ancash but did not fall sick until about ten or twelve
days after his arrival in Callao. They made quite a point of
his having come down from up the coast, but this to me had no
importance as I have practically no uneasiness about that sec-
tion of the coast. There have been no cases reported from there
and besides we have done fairly good work in all the coast towns
of that Department. Dr. Caballero has been over it several times
in addition to the work done by Corrigan and Sainz. Caballero
has recently returned to go over the coast again. If it could
have been a case it would mean that there has been a lurking
focus somewhere about Lima or Callao and that he contracted his
infection there. On this kind of a hypothesis I have decided
that the best thing to do is to remove any doubts and go ahead
with the clean up of all the coast at least as far south as
Chorillos which will insure the outcome of the campaign and en-
able us to accomplish our object of eliminating the fever this
year, unless there is something further south, in Ica for example.

For your information I am enclosing copy of letter to
Dr. Rose, and as I am writing Miss Read today I will send her a
copy of the last letter I wrote you on this matter, also of
this as it may serve as information to the board and save me a
bit of time explaining things.

On account of the extent of the territory which we are
watching I have arranged for Seeley to bring his family down
and stay with me until we finish. He has done very good work and
is very reliable and I will be able to depend on him for the
northern section, i.e., the Department of Lambayeque and probably
2. Dr. H.R. Carter, November 22, 1921.
also an occasional supervision of the Province of Pacasmayo.

I was surprised the other day while in Lima to get a cable
from Corrigan that Fisher would allow him to come back, and in
the cable he stated that he would leave it to me to fix his
salary. I cabled back that I could not offer him over $450.00
and if he wanted to come at that to come on with Seeley. I also
cabled Rose at the same time and he evidently agreed as he said
nothing to the contrary in the cable replying to some other
matters in my message. I had told Seeley to get Bumiller and I
had authorized him to offer Bumiller $350.00, but when Seeley
arrived in Panama Bumiller had gone to the states, I had pre-
viously sent a message for him to wait a few days but this
miserable telegraph we have had so balled my message up that
it had an entirely different meaning when Fisher received it.

On account of the high stegomya index which we continue to
find as we advance to the south I have decided that the only
safe thing to do is to continue with the cleaning up process.
It will cost the I.H.B., a little more money, but the thing they
are after is to make sure and in such a case it is poor policy
to economize too much. I did not expect to be obliged to continue
with the high priced supervision until we concluded to clean up
everything from the Rimac valley north. The condition in the
Rimac valley and in the valley of the Chillon could be a danger-
ous one and remain as a residual if left as it is now.

When Corrigan comes I shall have him take up the work on the
coast where Dunn has been working. Corrigan and Caballero can
control everything from the Chancay valley in the Department of
Lima to the Southern boundry of the Department of Libertad and
Tapia is taking good care of the Province of Trujillo with
Machado and Ramirez as supervising inspectors. Valdivieso who has
been acting as general supervising inspector in this province will
now be transferred to the southern sector to work with Mendoza in
the south. I have also transferred Benites from Guadelupe to
Callao and Adrienzen has the supervision of the whole province of
Pacasmayo. He has several young fellows there who have turned out
to be good reliable visitadores.

Before we conclude the campaign I shall probably make a tour
of inspection farther south, with the object of ascertaining what
has happened if anything in Ica where they have a great deal of
hot weather and stegomya breeding.

In the cable from Rose received today he states that he ex-
pects me to continue until April or May. This is the time which
I now think it necessary to continue the campaign. Now that we
have established an office in Lima I shall bring my family back
I have secured a completely furnished house in Miraflores in
which we can manage to get along until the closing of the cam-
paign. Martha objects very strenuously to being away from her
Daddy, also her Daddy objects to being away from her all the time.

I dont know what arrangements Mrs. Hanson has made about Karl.
If she brings him back I shall put him to work with Dunn in the
stegomya research, this will keep him both interested an occupied
and may be of some help to Dunn.

Trusting that you will let me know what you think about this
program, I am with best wishes,
